name: SRI
introduction: In the early 1970s, when the ARPANET was still an experiment rather than an infrastructure, Stanford Research Institute (SRI) in Menlo Park served as one of the network’s most important and influential sites. Known officially in the network tables as SRI-ARC (the Augmentation Research Center) and SRI-AI (the Artificial Intelligence Center), the SRI node housed some of the most advanced computing research in the world and played a central role in shaping what would eventually become the Internet.
about_host_0:
The star of the SRI node was the SDS 940, a time-sharing mainframe that ran Doug Engelbart’s revolutionary NLS (oN-Line System).
It was used for:
- interactive text editing
- hypertext linking
- screen windows
- remote shared editing
-collaborative conferencing (Journal and Dialogue systems)
- early email-like messaging
- project documentation systems

This single machine played an outsized historical role. It was the host machine for the famous 1968 “Mother of All Demos”, where Engelbart and his team demonstrated the mouse, hypertext, shared screens, videoconferencing, and real-time collaboration — long before they existed elsewhere.

By the time NLS was on the ARPANET, remote researchers could log in from any other ARPANET terminal and use the system just as local ARC researchers did.
about1_host_0: Functions as a research facility for the SRI Augmentation Research Center and the SRI Network Information Center.

about_host_1:
SRI also operated PDP-10 machines at the SRI AI Center (SAIL) and at ARC:
- Used for early artificial intelligence research
- Natural-language systems
- Early robotics work
- Symbolic computation
- Route-planning research (which later influenced navigation systems)

The PDP-10s communicated with the IMP via host interface hardware designed in collaboration with BBN engineers.

PDP-10 systems at SRI were well known for running experimental operating systems and knowledge-engineering tools. SRI’s AI researchers were among the heaviest ARPANET users, frequently logging into remote sites for collaboration.

introduction2:
SRI’s IMP (Interface Message Processor) was among the earliest deployed—connected in 1969 as one of the first four ARPANET sites alongside UCLA, UCSB, and the University of Utah.
The IMP at SRI typically sat in the machine room near the SDS 940, humming beside the refrigerator-sized computers and racks of modem lines.
The IMP connected SRI to the growing national network via a 50 kbps line, and from that single blue Honeywell box branched out the local interfaces to the center’s internal machines.
people_anecdotes:
People and Culture


SRI’s node was defined as much by the people who worked around it as by the machines themselves. Two organizational centers were particularly central: the Augmentation Research Center (ARC) led by Doug Engelbart, and the SRI AI programs.


Doug Engelbart and the ARC


Doug Engelbart and his ARC team were pioneers of collaborative computing. Engelbart’s long‑running project aimed to “augment human intellect” through tools that supported shared work, linking, and real‑time interaction. The NLS system, the mouse, and the experimental collaboration tools emerged from this mindset.


The ARC team included engineers and researchers who later influenced graphical user interfaces, hypertext systems, and collaborative software. Their work exemplified a purposeful, mission‑driven lab culture in which technology served to extend human cognitive capacity.



The AI Center and Robotics Researchers


SRI’s AI researchers — working on robotics, planning, and language understanding — used the ARPANET to share code, data, and results with remote collaborators. Their experimental code and datasets often crossed the network, speeding the pace of discovery.



Anecdotes and Notable Moments



The First Message


When the ARPANET first linked multiple sites, the earliest exchange produced the humble string “lo.” The system had crashed after transmission began, so the first transmitted characters were literally “lo,” a small but memorable beginning for what would become global communications.


The NLS Demo Room as a Hub


Following Engelbart’s 1968 demonstrations, the NLS console and demo space became a proto‑teleconferencing center. Remote researchers could log into the SDS 940 and witness edits and link manipulations in real time — an early incarnation of collaborative editing and remote meetings.


Robotics and Remote Computing


SRI’s robotics projects occasionally transferred control code and datasets across the ARPANET. Researchers joked that the robots were among the earliest 'network‑aware' devices, downloading software and directives over the same lines that connected human researchers.

name: BBN
introduction:
When historians trace the beginnings of the Internet, the trail always leads back to one modest building at Bolt Beranek and Newman (BBN) in Cambridge, Massachusetts. In late 1969, BBN hosted one of the first four ARPANET nodes—not just a participant, but the place where the network’s core equipment, the Interface Message Processor (IMP), had actually been designed and built.BBN’s node became a hub for early networking research, experimentation, and operations. The team that ran it were hands-on pioneers, working long nights wiring coaxial cables, debugging packet-switching code, and literally inventing what a computer network should be.

BBN designed and supplied their IMPs to all the nodes. Also, they managed the IMPs out in the field remotely. And that included doing the first remote firmware updates, and running the NCC (Network Control Center). The latter ran, interestingly, for many years using a 1959 PDP-1, which was also used to develop the IMP firmware. The setup of the BBN node was unique: connected to its regular IMP was a 316 IMP upgraded to be a TIP used for testing software updates and acting as the NCC (Network Control Center), with its own node number 40, and one more TIP, with its own node number 30.
about_host_0:
The PDP-10 became the backbone machine at BBN for network software. Many early network tools, including early mail transfer experiments and resource-sharing tests, were run on this system. It supported multiple users over terminals and was the main machine on which:
- ARPANET protocols were tested
- early email software was written and debugged
- host-to-host communication experiments were performed

BBN had a legendary DEC PDP-1, used for research and algorithm development. It wasn’t a production system so much as a platform for trying new ideas—visual displays, AI experiments, and even interactive graphics.
The PDP-1 was used heavily by the group working on packet-routing algorithms and traffic measurement. It was one of the earliest machines ever connected to the network.

introduction2:
The centerpiece of the node was the IMP, built from rugged Honeywell DDP-516 minicomputers. These machines were chosen because they were fast for their time, durable, and could run continuously without babysitting. Each IMP served as a small, dedicated packet switch—something entirely new in the late 1960s.

BBN’s IMP, like all of the early ones, connected to local host computers through 1822 interfaces (named after the protocol BBN devised). The hosts attached at BBN varied over time, but the early ones typically included:
people_anecdotes:
Human Side: The Team Behind the Network

The BBN networking group was small, tightly knit, and famously overworked. They were engineers of a special kind—mathematicians, software developers, hardware specialists, and systems thinkers all rolled together. Many later became legendary figures in computer science.

Frank Heart – The Quiet Leader

Frank Heart led the IMP project with a calm, disciplined style. He insisted on reliability, redundancy, and solid engineering—values that shaped the entire design of the network.

He was known for:

  • defending the team when deadlines seemed impossible
  • insisting that the IMPs survive power failures, crashes, and abuse
  • keeping the group focused through months of around-the-clock work

His leadership directly influenced the Internet’s reputation for resilience.

Severo Ornstein – Designer of the IMP Hardware

A hardware wizard, Ornstein helped design the custom interfaces and timing circuits that let the IMP survive real-world conditions. Coworkers joked that he could “hear” logic faults in oscilloscopes the way a musician hears wrong notes.

He later wrote beautifully about working nights soldering, debugging, and thinking about packet-switching long before anyone knew it would take over the world.

Will Crowther – Software Engineer and Adventurer

Crowther wrote significant portions of the IMP’s software stack. He later became famous for creating Colossal Cave Adventure, the first text adventure game.

At BBN, he was known for:

  • sleeping under his desk during long debugging sessions
  • rock climbing on weekends
  • calm, minimalistic coding that saved the team countless hours

Dave Walden – IMP Systems Programmer

Walden wrote much of the 1822 host/IMP interface software and host-to-host protocol implementation. He produced extremely clear documentation that made connecting a new host possible.

He once recounted that the documentation for 1822 “was sometimes more carefully read than the Bible” by early ARPANET engineers.

BBN Receptionist Who Became an ARPANET Operator

One often-told story is that the BBN receptionist—who had no technical background—was trained to watch the blinking lights of the IMP status indicators so she could alert the engineers when the network behaved strangely. It was an early form of NOC monitoring.

Anecdotes From the Early Days

The First IMP Shipment

When BBN delivered the very first IMP to UCLA in 1969, they shipped it in a wooden crate. The UCLA team expected a small computer. Instead, they received something the size of a dishwasher—massive, heavy, and industrial-looking.

BBN engineers joked afterward:
“That was the moment the Internet physically arrived.”

Debugging With Paper Tape

Much of the early IMP code was stored on paper tape. If a tape was dropped or torn, someone had to manually hold it together while feeding it into the reader. Once, after a long night of debugging, Crowther accidentally fed the tape upside-down and backward, creating chaos on the console before they realized the mistake.

The Network Collapse That Wasn’t

BBN sometimes received panicked calls from remote sites reporting that 'the network is down.' In one famous case, the BBN team rushed to diagnose the packet logs, only to discover that the user’s terminal paper had simply run out, giving the illusion of a frozen machine.

BBN’s PDP-10 as a Social Hub

Because BBN offered a powerful time-sharing system connected to the ARPANET, researchers at other sites often logged in remotely—sometimes for legitimate work, sometimes to chat, experiment, or simply explore.

This created one of the earliest “online communities,” decades before the Web existed.

Why the BBN Node Matters

The BBN node wasn’t just another site on the network. It was the birthplace of the devices that made ARPANET possible. It served as:

  • a development laboratory
  • a testbed for protocols
  • an unofficial help desk for the entire network
  • a gathering place for some of the most creative and driven computer scientists of their time

In many ways, the networking culture—collaborative, hacker-friendly, experimentally driven—was shaped by the atmosphere at BBN during these years.

BBN’s node was where the Internet’s DNA was written.

name: MIT
introduction: MIT’s ARPANET node in 1973 was one of the network’s busiest and most technically ambitious sites. A single IMP linked three PDP-10 time-sharing systems—serving the DM group, the AI Lab, and other campus users—together with the H-645 Multics machine, then one of the most sophisticated operating systems in active development. This concentration of powerful hosts and pioneering researchers made MIT a focal point for early work on interactive computing, operating-system design, and emerging network protocols. The node handled heavy academic use, experimental software, and collaborative projects that rippled through the wider ARPANET community, giving MIT an influence disproportionate even to its substantial size.
about_host_0: The H-645 Multics system at MIT in 1973 (replaced during the year by a H-6180) was one of the most advanced machines on the ARPANET and served as a primary development platform for the Multics operating system itself. Built on Honeywell hardware and jointly developed by MIT, Bell Labs, and Honeywell, Multics introduced concepts such as a single-level hierarchical file system, dynamic linking, segmented memory, fine-grained security controls, and robust multiuser time-sharing. On the ARPANET, the MIT Multics host provided remote researchers with access to these capabilities, making it a reference system for studies in system security, modular software design, and high-reliability computing. Its design strongly influenced later systems—notably Unix—and its network presence allowed ARPANET users to experiment with ideas that were conceptually ahead of most contemporary hosts.
about1_host_0: MIT’s H-645 Multics system in 1973 was a Honeywell 645 mainframe, built to handle multiple users at once and run complex programs smoothly. It had several CPUs that could work simultaneously, plenty of core memory for the time, and a unique memory-segmentation design that kept different users’ programs safely separated. High-speed disks and tape drives stored data and programs, while multiple terminals and network connections allowed researchers across campus—and on the ARPANET—to log in and use the system at the same time. The machine’s architecture was designed for heavy, interactive use, letting many people compile code, run experiments, and explore new computing ideas without getting in each other’s way.
about2_host_0: The MIT H-645 Multics system had a profound influence on later computing, both technically and culturally. Its ambitious design—featuring hierarchical file systems, dynamic linking, hardware-enforced security, and robust multiuser time-sharing—pushed the boundaries of what an operating system could do, but also made it complex, sometimes unwieldy, and slow by comparison to simpler systems. Students and researchers loved its power and elegance, yet often frustrated by its size and complexity, giving rise to the famous “love/hate” reputation. Multics directly inspired the development of the Incompatible Timesharing System (ITS) at MIT, which adopted a lighter, more flexible approach, and later heavily influenced Unix, whose designers sought to retain Multics’ best ideas—like hierarchical file systems and modular design—while avoiding its cumbersome overhead. In this way, Multics became both a benchmark and a cautionary tale.
about_host_1: The Dynamic Modeling (DM) group at MIT operated a dedicated PDP-10 mainframe connected to the ARPANET through the MIT IMP. Like the AI Lab’s PDP-10, it was a 36-bit machine with substantial core memory and multiple high-speed registers, optimized for time-sharing. The system supported simultaneous interactive sessions for a number of researchers, and its hardware was well suited for intensive computation
about1_host_1: DM was a PDP-10, specifically, a KA10, that primarily served system-software research, mathematical modeling, and network experimentation. It was used to test and develop concepts in resource-sharing, scheduling, and early distributed computing, making it a hub for experimental network protocols and time-sharing techniques. Photo above is a KA10 stock photo
about2_host_1:
The DM PDP-10 fostered a culture of serious experimentation mixed with playful exploration, typical of MIT’s hacker ethos. While it lacked the sheer volume of Lisp-based AI projects on the AI Lab PDP-10, it offered a rich environment of software tools, compilers, and modeling utilities that researchers could freely modify and expand. Work on this node influenced the development of operating-system concepts, time-sharing strategies, and early ideas that would feed into systems like ITS and the broader ARPANET software culture. The DM PDP-10 was both a workhorse for computation and a proving ground for novel software.

DMS provides the popular and very useful SURVEY program, allowing users to survey the current state of Arpanet nodes.
about_host_2: The MIT AI Lab ran a PDP-10 mainframe, a 36-bit machine well suited for interactive, time-sharing workloads. It had multiple high-speed registers, sizable core memory for the era, and could support many simultaneous users through its time-sharing capabilities. The system connected to multiple terminals across the lab and to the ARPANET, enabling researchers to log in remotely and run programs concurrently. Its hardware was optimized for symbolic computation, AI experiments, and rapid program compilation, making it a versatile and responsive platform for the lab’s diverse projects.
about1_host_2: AI Lab’s PDP-10 served as a central hub for artificial intelligence research, particularly in Lisp programming, robotics, and early interactive AI experiments. It handled heavy time-sharing loads, supported experimental software development, and allowed researchers across MIT—and via the ARPANET, elsewhere—to collaborate and test new ideas in real time. The machine’s accessibility and responsiveness made the AI Lab node one of the busiest and most innovative points on the network.
about2_host_2: The AI Lab PDP-10 made MIT by far the most 'fun' node on Arpanet. It quickly became the center of MIT’s legendary hacker culture. Running the Incompatible Timesharing System (ITS), the machine offered a vast playground filled with experimental tools, programming environments, and a ton of software to explore, modify, and share. Click to zoom in on the above images; the remarkable thing is that all of this has been preserved and now is available in the modern PiDP-10 replica (which is online in our Arpanet Reconstruction). See the PiDP-10 pages for wht you can do. ITS encouraged playful experimentation and code tinkering, fostering a spirit of creativity and collaboration that directly influenced the early open-source movement. It spawned things like Emacs, countless utilities and programming languages, all developed in an environment where exploration and pushing the system to its limits was explicitly the goal.
about_host_3: The ML PDP-10 served as a primary platform for early machine learning research, including pattern recognition, computational linguistics, and exploratory AI algorithms. It supported both the development of experimental programs and collaboration with other ARPANET nodes.
about1_host_3:
The MIT Machine Learning (ML) group operated its own PDP-10 mainframe, similar to the AI and DM systems.

ML hosted the MACSYMA algebraic system, the first symbolic math software.
about2_host_3: The ML PDP-10 served as a primary platform for early machine learning research, including pattern recognition, computational linguistics, and exploratory AI algorithms. It supported both the development of experimental programs and collaboration with other ARPANET nodes..
introduction2: MIT hosted four distinct systems. The AI Lab’s PDP-10 was heavily used for Lisp development, robotics work, and early interactive programs that pushed the limits of time-sharing across the net. The Dynamic Modeling (DM) PDP-10 supported system-software research, mathematical modeling, and experiments in resource-sharing that shaped later networked operating-system ideas. The Machine Learning (ML) PDP-10—sometimes referred to as the MAC-ML system—served a broad community working on pattern recognition, computational linguistics, and early AI techniques. The H-645 Multics machine was a radically different computing culture: a secure, modular, multiuser OS whose file-system design, networking interfaces, and programming tools became widely studied - famous and infamous to some. Together, MIT had by far the richest and most diverse cluster of systems, each attracting its own community and collectively making MIT the most interesting node on the network.
people_anecdotes:
At MIT, the computing environment in 1973 was a unique blend of experimentation, collaboration, and rigorous system design. The AI Lab, DM group, and ML group each had dedicated PDP-10 systems connected to the ARPANET, while the Multics H-645 provided a separate high-performance mainframe environment. Together, these machines supported a dense community of researchers who shared terminals, software, and ideas freely. The culture emphasized interactive experimentation, playful exploration, and hands-on learning: researchers were encouraged to modify code, experiment with operating systems, and develop new software tools. This environment fostered both serious research—on operating systems, time-sharing, and network protocols—and more creative projects, such as early AI experiments, simulations, and programming language development.

Within this collaborative and highly experimental culture, certain individuals became particularly influential. At the AI Lab, Richard D. Greenblatt emerged as a central figure, known for his work on MacLisp and the MacHack VI chess program, and for embodying the hacker ethos of playful, boundary-pushing programming. In the Multics project, Jerry Saltzer contributed foundational ideas for system architecture, security, and process management, helping shape Multics into a robust, multiuser environment that influenced future operating systems, including Unix. The DM and ML groups, while less highlighted in popular histories, were staffed by graduate students and researchers focused on system-software experiments, modeling, and early machine learning algorithms. Their work involved testing resource-sharing strategies, developing scheduling and time-sharing methods, and running computationally intensive experiments, all of which supported the broader MIT research mission.

Together, these groups created an ecosystem that was as much about people and collaboration as it was about machines. The AI Lab’s PDP-10 fostered a hacker culture with a wealth of experimental software, while the DM and ML systems provided rigorous platforms for testing computing concepts. Multics offered a contrasting but complementary environment of careful system engineering and robust multiuser computing. The interactions between these groups—through shared terminals, code, and ARPANET connectivity—helped cultivate innovations in open collaboration, experimental software, and early concepts that would eventually influence open-source practices, the development of tools like Emacs, and many of the principles of modern interactive computing. This mixture of creative freedom, technical rigor, and community interaction defined MIT’s computing culture in the early ARPANET era.

He proposed a communication network with no central command point. If one point was destroyed, all surviving points would still be able to communicate with each other. He called this a distributed network. With that, he laid one of the roots of Arpanet.

name: ILLINOIS
introduction:
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Center for Advanced Computation

on November 3, 1970, the Center was conceived to facilitate full utilization and exploitation of the potentials of the ILLIAC IV computer by acting as a liaison facility between computer technologists and experts in the physical, life, and social sciences. Construction of the ILLIAC IV was removed from this campus to California. The Center had access to computational resources including the ILLIAC IV via the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network. It promoted interdisciplinary and applied research by developing numerical techniques and provided the educational, software and hardware development necessary to research faculty using the Center and the ARPA Network.

introduction: Case Western Reserve was one of the first universities connected to the ARPANET in 1971.

introduction2: The CWRU IMP lived in the Computing Center in Crawford Hall, where the university’s mainframes and timesharing systems were all located.
people_anecdotes:
Faculty in the engineering and systems programs pushed for joining the ARPANET early. The Crawford Hall Crew was a legendary cohort of graduate students and sysadmins who kept the IBM 360/67 running at all hours, sleeping under desks during exam week and inventing quirky local tools that spread across the network. A few achieved mild notoriety for experiments that tested ARPANET resilience late at night.

Like many ARPANET sites, CWRU relied on highly skilled student system operators. Many became early email adopters, writing the first local scripts for automating remote file retrieval.

Anecdotes and ARPANET Folklore from CWRU



Case vs. Carnegie Mellon Network Rivalry: Because CWRU’s nearest ARPANET neighbor was CMU, students traded network messages involving humorously bad ASCII art and competitive uptime bragging rights between the PDP-10s. One story claims that CWRU students wrote a script that, at login, sent a friendly greeting to CMU terminals if a CMU user was detected on a remote connection—sometimes confusing unsuspecting Pittsburgh students.

The Accidental Network Benchmark

A student once tried to copy a full disk image from the PDP-10 to a host at Illinois to 'see how fast the ARPANET is today'. The transfer ran for hours, frustrating users, and earned the student a firm note from the site’s ARPANET liaison: 'Please do not measure the network by trying to copy Ohio into Illinois.'

The First Email Wave at Case

CWRU students became enthusiastic early adopters of ARPANET email—so much so that the computing center had to issue a courtesy reminder, encouraging students not to email entire course assignments to each other, because the system disk was filling up.
One professor reportedly said '“My students discovered email, and productivity dropped—but creativity soared.'

Remote Logins to MIT and Stanford

CWRU’s PDP-10 users were frequent visitors to MIT-AI, SAIL, and SU-AI during off-hours. Logbooks from MIT describe seeing CASE– usernames showing up late at night, often testing out LISP systems or TECO macros.

The IMP Freeze due of a Student Driver Test

A student experimenting with a custom PDP-10 network driver accidentally triggered an invalid 1822 sequence that caused the IMP to refuse new host messages for several minutes. The Honeywell IMP operator console lit up like a Christmas tree. The note left afterward on the PDP-10 read: Please do not try to teach the IMP new tricks. The student later became a respected networking engineer, name witheld.

name: AMES
introduction: When the ARPANET moved out of its testbed in the early 1970s, NASA’s Ames Research Center was one of the government research labs tapped to join the experiment. Ames was an appealing ARPANET site: it combined heavy computational needs for aeronautics and simulation with an engineering culture comfortable with advanced computer systems. As such, Ames was one of the first government research centers to host an IMP and attach multiple powerful computers and TIP services to the network.
about_host_0: NASA Ames maintained IBM 360-class systems for heavy batch science and engineering jobs. The 360/67 family was popular at government labs because it supported virtual memory and timesharing variants — useful for both scheduled large simulation runs and interactive research sessions. Typical uses at Ames included aerodynamic simulations, structural analysis, and engineering toolchains such as NASTRAN. These mainframes often acted as the “official” data-processing centers for large projects; they ran heavy FORTRAN jobs, handled tape libraries, and stored large experiment datasets that collaborators could request over the ARPANET.e corrupti.

They were the usual birthplace for early network tools, email practices, and collaborative programming. At Ames, TENEX hosts and BBN-linked PDP-10s were the places people logged into for interactive work, mailbox use, and small-scale experiments.

about_host_2: Ames ran Terminal Interface Processors (TIPs) to let many ASCII terminals (from engineering consoles to remote collaborators) connect to the ARPANET without each terminal needing its own host. TIPs were an essential way that ARPANET spread beyond the handful of large computers to actual human users on terminals across a lab — greatly multiplying who could use the network for email, file transfer and remote login. Ames’s ARPANET entry in 1973 directories explicitly list TIP connections.

introduction2: Ames’s IMP was the focal point for several different kinds of hosts: large scientific mainframes, time-sharing systems, experimental supercomputers, and Terminal Interface Processors (TIPs) that let many local terminals access the network without a dedicated host.
people_anecdotes:
Ames’s aviation work required massive simulations. Large FORTRAN jobs ran on the 360 family; results were exchanged with other universities by file transfer. Structural and systems analysis (NASTRAN) simulations ran as queued jobs on the mainframes; ARPANET was used to submit jobs remotely and fetch results. Interactive research & software development was done on the TENEX/PDP-10 hostas well as human–computer interaction experiments and interactive data analysis. These machines were the social centers where algorithms and tools were developed and shared.

ACM Digital Library

Ames researchers could pull telemetry, datasets, documentation, and code from other labs (and receive mail) — functionally the same roles ARPANET played at other research sites. The TIPs made the network accessible to non-programmer researchers and engineers on terminals across Ames.

People

Ames’s ARPANET life was run by a mix of groups: NASA scientific staff, central computing facility personnel, systems programmers, and student or contractor engineers assigned to specific projects. Contemporary ARPANET participant lists and RFC distributions name network liaisons and contacts tied to Ames (for example, figures listed as contacts in RFC-era distribution lists), showing the institutional organization behind network participation. These liaisons bridged the technical needs of aeronautics projects with ARPA’s networking requirements.

Because Ames combined government lab discipline with a research-lab attitude, the culture around the computers tended to be a mix of careful systems engineering and hands-on curiosity: staff expected heavy, scheduled simulations to run cleanly, but they also encouraged experiments on network protocols and interactive tools that pushed the state of the art.

Anecdotes & human moments



The presence of large specialized supercomputers at Ames meant the ARPANET occasionally moved truly massive datasets for the time — returning results from CFD runs that would have been impossible to ship on tape quickly. Those transfers often tested both human patience and the network’s patience; scheduling became an art.

The TIP as a social portal

Engineers and visitors used TIP-attached terminals to exchange informal email, quick notes, and early mail group coordination. The TIPs were actually where non-programmers first saw the power of the network.

name: MITRE
introduction:
MITRE joined the ARPA computer network in September 1971 when a Terminal Interface Message Processor (TIP) was installed at its Washington location, according to RFC 321.

The Node: TIP vs. IMP + Host

The node was explicitly identified as a TIP, not an IMP + host configuration.

  • A TIP was designed primarily for terminal-based access, allowing multiple local terminals to initiate sessions with remote ARPANET hosts.
  • This configuration suggests MITRE's connection was for outward access and did not host a large data-serving mainframe or bulk-data server for the network.

MITRE was therefore among the first wave of TIP-based nodes, representing the early diversification of the ARPANET beyond the large host installations.

Usage and Contribution

MITRE used the ARPANET for both internal research and architectural development:

1. Internal Use and Research (IR&D)

MITRE’s use of the network was largely supported by **IR&D funds** (internal Research and Development) and was explicitly aimed at:

  • Promoting the operational use of network resources within MITRE.
  • Using the ARPANET itself as a **research tool** for networking experiments.
  • Demonstrating how ARPANET resources could extend existing systems’ capabilities.

Thus, MITRE’s role was dual: as a **network-user** for internal projects and as a participant in early **networking research**.

2. Conceptual Protocol Work

MITRE did more than just consume resources; its researchers contributed to the network's evolution. For example, **M. A. Padlipsky of MITRE Corporation** authored or co-authored important early documents, including **RFC 871 — “A Perspective on the ARPANET Reference Model.”**

name: NBS
introduction:
NBS (National Bureau of Standards, now NIST)

NBS’s ARPANET node served a government laboratory with interests in standards, measurement, and scientific computing. The hosts attached to their IMP ran experiments, shared datasets, and participated in standardization discussions that shaped early networking practices.

Computers and uses

NBS used its connected systems for measurements, protocol experiments, and collaborative work on standards. The site’s emphasis on measurement and reproducibility made it an important contributor to early discussions about how to evaluate network performance and interoperability.

People and team

NBS teams helped bring a scientific rigor to some early ARPANET measurements and conformance testing. NBS staff supplied detailed reports on network behavior that informed later protocol tweaks and measurement strategies—work that quietly shaped how engineers thought about network reliability.

name: ETAC
introduction:
The Environmental Technical Applications Center (ETAC) was part of the U.S. Air Force Air Weather Service (AWS).

Its mission, as documented in Air Weather Service publications from the 1970s, included:

  • long-range climatology
  • environmental statistics
  • atmospheric risk assessment for military planning
  • production of standardized environmental summaries for USAF operational units

Sources:

  • History of the Air Weather Service, USAF Historical Studies (annual volumes, early 1970s).
  • AWS Publication: “Environmental Technical Applications Center: Mission and Functions.”

2. ETAC’s Appearance on the ARPANET

ETAC appears explicitly in ARPANET host and node listings beginning in 1973–1974 under the designation:

ETAC-TIP

This designation occurs in:

  • ARPANET Host Tables
  • ARPANET Node Lists compiled by the Defense Communications Agency (DCA)
  • RFC-series Host Status documents

Source:

  • RFC 597: “Host Status” (December 1973 / March 1974 updates).

3. ETAC’s ARPANET Hardware

TIP (Terminal Interface Processor)

ETAC's node type is listed as a TIP, not an IMP.

A TIP (Terminal Interface Processor):

  • was produced by BBN, based on Honeywell 316 hardware
  • allowed multiple terminals at a site to initiate sessions with remote ARPANET hosts
  • typically did not provide host-computer service to the ARPANET
  • was intended for outward remote access rather than dataset hosting

Sources:

  • BBN Report 1822: “Specifications for the Interconnection of a Host and an IMP.”
  • BBN Report 3068: “Terminal Interface Processor (TIP) User’s Guide,” 1972.
  • DCA ARPANET Node Maps (1973–1974).

Local Computer: PDP-11/45

In RFC 597’s Host Status table, ETAC’s entry lists the CPU as:

PDP-11/45 (a DEC minicomputer)

A PDP-11/45 was a mid-range 16-bit system widely used by USAF and DoD organizations for data processing and administrative tasks.

Source:

  • RFC 597, Host Status Table, entry for ETAC-TIP (1974).

4. ETAC’s Function on the ARPANET

Based on the TIP role and the PDP-11/45 host class, ETAC’s ARPANET usage can be described factually as follows:

Terminal Access:

The TIP enabled ETAC personnel to initiate terminal sessions with remote ARPANET hosts.

Remote Computing:

ETAC used ARPANET connections to access computational resources located at other ARPANET nodes (e.g., research institutions, DoD labs).

This follows from TIP design: TIPs did not host remote users but enabled local users to connect outward.

Not a Data-Serving Host:

Because ETAC was a TIP node and its local system was a PDP-11/45, there is no evidence that ETAC provided large datasets over the ARPANET.

TIP nodes were not designed for bulk data distribution.

name: FNWC
introduction:
The Fleet Numerical Weather Center (FNWC), part of the U.S. Navy, fell under the Naval Oceanography Command.

Mission and Role

FNWC’s primary mission was to provide **global meteorology and oceanography support** for:

  • Fleet operations
  • Naval aviation
  • Strategic planning

FNWC served as the U.S. Navy’s **central facility for global ocean and weather forecasting**.

Hardware and Connectivity

FNWC initially connected to the ARPANET via a **FNWC-TIP**, providing a **terminal interface** for local personnel to access remote hosts.

Soon after, the organization’s host computer was brought online. This was a **CDC 6500** (or possibly an earlier CDC 3200), which provided **heavy weather and oceanographic processing** capabilities to the network.

name: BELVOIR
introduction:
Fort Belvoir, located in northern Virginia, was one of a number of U.S. Army installations that participated in the ARPANET during the early–mid 1970s. Most military nodes existed not to run open research-linked academic software like at the university sites, but rather to connect command-and-control research labs, engineering groups, and logistics systems to the broader ARPA research network.

The Belvoir node typically appears in ARPANET topology maps as simply “BELVOIR”, sometimes with sub-labels depending on the specific host connected.
Exact host designations varied by year, but Belvoir generally connected Army R&D computers, commonly used for engineering design, Mapping and geospatial analysis, Logistics and supply modeling, as well as Communications R&D and testing



Belvoir was never a large multi-host ARPANET node like BBN or SRI; in later years it usually had 1–2 hosts attached.

Belvoir staff used university and BBN systems for time-sharing; and served as a participant in military network experiments.

introduction2: Belvoir was part of a cluster of East Coast military ARPANET nodes, including Aberdeen Proving Ground and the NBS (National Bureau of Standards). Earlier maps do not list it; after the mid-1970s, it disappears as DoD networking shifted toward the later ARPANET-minimized MILNET structures.
people_anecdotes: Unlike sites such as BBN or SRI, ARPANET-era personal anecdotes from Belvoir are scarce. But the node was run by Army Signal Corps communications engineers. Systems operators were usually civilian DoD employees or contractors. Many staff were involved in command-and-control simulation, mapping, or communications reliability research—fields that ARPA funded heavily. Personnel from Belvoir contributed to early network reliability studies and testing reports, though individual names do not appear in surviving public documents.

name: LBL
introduction:
LBL (now Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory) in Berkeley, California, was an ARPANET site connected in the early 1970s. It was one of several Department of Energy–associated research labs (then AEC/ERDA) to join the network. The site played a role in early scientific computing and data-sharing across the high-energy physics community.

LBL’s ARPANET node connected large scientific computers used for physics simulations and experimental data processing, connections to UC Berkeley played the main role.

LBL used several machines over time, but the key systems during the 1970–1975 period were CDC 6600 / CDC 6400 / CDC 7600 (large scientific mainframes) and PDP-10 systems (shared with or connected via UC Berkeley). Those seem not yet to have been brought online in early 1973 though.

introduction2:
The LBL ARPANET Node Was Used For:
1. Sharing high-performance computing; other ARPANET sites could remotely submit physics simulation jobs, access datasets, and collaborate on multi-lab projects. This was one of the visionary ARPANET goals: shared access to scarce supercomputers.
2. Data exchange for the high-energy physics community: LBL, SLAC (Stanford Linear Accelerator Center), LLNL, and other labs were early adopters of digital data sharing. Especially, SLAC and LBL exchanged detector data, beamline summaries, and analysis output across the ARPANET.
3. Early email and collaboration culture: LBL researchers were among the first to exchange scientific results via email and use early mailing lists as scientific discussion groups.
people_anecdotes:
Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory (LBL) on the ARPANET

Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory (LBL) connected to the ARPANET in the **early/mid-1970s**, making it one of the relatively early non-academic (national lab / government-research) sites to join the network.

The CDC 6600 Supercomputer

LBL’s history page states that in **1974** its **“CDC 6600 became the first supercomputer connected to ARPANET.”**

  • The CDC 6600 had been installed at LBL in **1965** and was widely regarded as the world’s first successful supercomputer.
  • Though the **IMP** (Interface Message Processor) appears on ARPANET maps as early as **1973**, the host machine was not fully put online until 1974.

National Data Center Vision

This connection aligned with LBL's ambition to become a major computational resource. A “scientific data center” white paper from the early 1970s proposed LBL serve as a **National Scientific Data Center** to provide computing and data services to external users (i.e., across institutions) via remote-access, which the ARPANET connection made possible.
